name: Surgeon Simulator
description: Surgeon Simulator is an over-the-top operation sim, stitching together pitch-black humour with life-saving surgery. Become Dr. Burke, a would-be surgeon with a less than conventional toolkit, as he performs procedures on patients including none other than Donald Trump, himself! ...is that a hammer?
minimum_requirements: OS:Windows XP Processor:2.0 GHz Memory:2 GB RAM Graphics:Nvidia Geforce 7800 GT or better DirectX®:9.0 Hard Drive:500 MB HD space Sound:DirectX9.0 compatible sound card Additional:Requires keyboard. Touchpad supported, but mouse strongly recommended for best play experience.
recommended_requirements: OS:Windows 7 Processor:2.0 GHz or better Memory:2 GB RAM Graphics:Radeon x850 or comparable DirectX®:9.0 Hard Drive:500 MB HD space Sound:DirectX9.0 compatible sound card Additional:Requires keyboard. Touchpad supported, but mouse strongly recommended for best play experience.

reviews.review_text: I've always wanted to become a doctor, and this game fully prepared me. Not even kidding. I performed my first real life surgery yesterday.  Kidney transplant. With a motherf**king pencil. Ended up switching the man's kidneys with a fire extinguisher and a watch.  We laughed it off at the end though, so everything is cool. He likes his new kidneys.
As a real surgery man, i can confirm this is how hospital people do surgeries.

A hyper-realistic surgical procedure simulation program, likely used the world over to train medical professionals. Playing this intense game, you get put second-by-second in total control of a mans life.  The real world physics and photo-realistic graphics, combined with the Oculus Rift support makes this an unforgettable experience, almost identical to performing real open heart surgery yourself. As such, it is a very gory game and should not be attempted or even purchased by the weak of stomach or those with a tremorous disposition. It is also impossibly difficult, requiring a stready hand, a sweaty brow and utmost focus. Do NOT play if alone, under the age of 18 or have not had 3 years in medical school beforehand.   Highly difficult, very realistic, outstandingly educational. I look forward to future productions from this outstanding simulation company.

I have no idea if you are going to like this game. It's a weird, hard to control, bizarre game. People compare it to QWOP and to the extent that it relies on playing twister with your fingers that's true, but it's much more than that. Each surgery is like a puzzle, trying to figure out which tools work and don't, finding the most efficient route through it. Achievements incentivize creative play. I mean, the most amazing thing about the game is that it exists at all, it's so absurd. But I think if you get past the initial curve you'll find a compelling score/time attack game.  I'll also add that if you have people over to your house, non-gamers LOVE watching this. A casual hammer to the skull here, a drill dropped in a chest cavity there, accidentally throwing the replacement heart away. It's all good.  You're looking at 8-10 hours for completion of every surgery with good scores, maybe 12-15 if you want to go to A++ on everything. The developers have also repeatedly updated the game with new free content, so I think it's fair to say that if you're the type that buys games to support a developer, this is a good choice.

Beyond the absurdity and the humor, Surgeon Simulator can only offer frustration. Poor controls are taken as a core design philosophy and buttressed with any restrictive obstacle that came to mind. This is not the hilarious but humbling exercise of realizing how difficult complicated basic movement really is, this is a constant fight against a game that not only has to struggle to understand what the player wants it to do but also has trouble preventing objects from phasing in and out of each other. The lesson this game has to teach, what it demands of its players, is that they put aside the anger born of uncooperative controls to practice patience and precision in a world that has none. It's quite clever really. Shame all that's left to look back on is annoyance after annoyance, which increases level by level in the name of some sense of progression.

Surgeon Simulator is one of these short joke games where the core of the gameplay is the hilarity that stems from overcoming intentionally awkward controls and buggy physics. You play as a newbie surgeon - or to be more precise, a clearly disembodied hand - who has to successfully complete various surgeries despite being clumsy as all hell.  Don't look for any kind of anatomical accuracy or realism in this game - ripping off the patient's organs and throwing them on the ground just to get to the one organ that needs replacement is a regular practice in the game, and the mission is considered completed if you manage to throw the new organ onto the spot where it's supposed to be. Even if said organ falls out immediately afterwards while the game merrily displays the success screen (which clearly suggests that the patient wasn't going to survive one way or another). The only thing you have to worry about regarding the patient is making sure that the blood level doesn't reach zero. And yes, you can still finish the mission even if the patient is left with as little as 1 ml of blood. This game exists to be a source of dark humor, not to be realistic.  You are given plenty of tools to accomplish various tasks and it's only up to you to decide what is going to be useful. Obligatory scalpels, various saws for cutting bones, drugs that either slow down or speed up the blood flow, and even axes, hammers and drills. Many of them, more often than not, are going to be only a hindrance in your desperate efforts, blocking your way to the actually important tools, bumping into the patient and making him lose blood, or even getting you high. And that's just the beginning.  As I mentioned, the game isn't very long; there is 9 levels total, plus 2 hidden, and the exact time it will take you to complete them for the first time will vary depending on how badly you'll be initially doing. There are 3 kinds of surgeries in 3 kinds of environments, so at some point you'll end up in a situation where, for example, you have to do a brain transplant in an ambulance that rides on a bumpy road, with the objects jumping up at random and the back door opening from time to time. Probably the funniest moment you are going to see in this game is successfully completing said surgery and then watching as the brain you just put in the patient's head falls out right away and ends up on the floor or even on the road. The mission is still accomplished, so who cares!  Surgeon Simulator is the kind of game that you either just can't stand, or love coming back to it despite how badly it frustrates you. And yes, after the initial hilarity wears off and you get better at playing it, you'll most likely start seeing the game's frustrating elements more and more. Probably the biggest one of them is how it can be a pain in the butt to actually grab things; there's NO indication whether you actually grabbed the damn object or not, usually resulting in you spending some time on the ritual of pressing the buttons to grab something and then raising the hand to see if you actually grabbed it.  Another problem is that the game gives you next to no information on how various things work. There is no tutorial at all; the only thing you get is the info on how to control the hand, which is displayed on the computer in the main menu (and the said menu uses the exact same hand mechanics as well, to make matters even better). The rest you either have to figure out yourself (most likely failing numerous times before you successfully complete a surgery at least once) or just Google things up. The game DOES give tips on certain things, but that's only AFTER you completed a surgery, and only if you figure out that you can put floppy disks into the computer in the main menu. And let me tell you, doing so can be frustratingly hard as well, since the computer will only accept them if they're perfectly aligned.  In the end, Surgeon Simulator is a little curiosity that some people will like, and some people will hate. My recommendation is to first play the demo provided by the creators of the game and see how well you'll do in it. If you'll end up loving the absurdity of the game, then I think you'll like the full game as well. But if you'll instead end up getting frustrated and/or freaking out over the patient dying, then I think you're better off giving up on this one.

I was expecting a top-of-the-line learning tool for medical studies, but am bitterly disappointed that this game is nothing at all like real surgery. I am shocked that they would even dare to call it a 'simulator'. The representation of the human body and its organs is laughable at best, the surgical processes are simplified to crude hammering, slicing, dicing and flinging, and my 'hands' act as if they're almost paralyzed, they're so cumbersome. Jack the Ripper himself would scoff at this brutal mess of a 'game'.  What could have been a helpful tool for the medical profession, and indeed for the betterment of humanity and the human condition, is reduced to outright nonsense. Look elsewhere if you are seeking a valuable learning experience. However, if utter mayhem involving helplesshuman bodies, all manner of blunt/sharp/shiny/pokey/breaky objects (medical and otherwise), and sheer unmitigated madness is your idea of a 'fun' time, then perhaps this offering is for you, you sad and demented person.  I know it's right up my street.  9/10

I reccomend this game. Listen, if you think I'm in no place to be judging it, take this into concideration: I legitimately got an A++ on every mission, and I got a 100% no blood loss brain sugery. I know what I'm talking about.   Lots of people complain about the way this game runs, but it runs perfectly for me and I have a terrible pc. I can barely run skyrim on medium graphics. This game runs perfectly if you want to mess with the options a small bit.     The game's controls are terrible.  BUT THAT'S THE POINT. YOU'RE PLAYING AS A DRUGGED UP SURGEON. YOU'RE NOT MEANT TO BE IN CONTROL OF A SOBER HUMAN, YOU PLAY AS NIGEL BURK, A MAN ADDICTED TO PILLS.   Hence why he has drugs on his desk (pills) and why you can inject yourself with the hallucinatory drugs during the operations. If you still feel like I don't know enough about this game, I can tell you that I have all of the achievements :/  I definately reccomend this game, it's long, it takes a while to learn, and it's fun. Slamming radios into people's ribcages is fun. Drilling a hole in your patient's head is fun. Making your patient a timelord is fun. Getting every mission A++'d is fun.  This game is fun. I reccomend it especially with the new update for the anniversary coming out.

Surgeon Simulator 2013 is a massively enjoyable indie game and brings a new meaning to the word 'original'. The never seen before gameplay style is a fantastic novelty and matched up against the hilarious content, visuals and audio brings a new experience to gamers which you will no doubt have fun with. The one thing that this game does lack, however, is content. With just a few hours of purely original content available to the player, there isn't a great deal to do. Luckily for the player, the mechanics and style of the game make it such an enjoyment to replay that you can get hours of fun from repeating operations.   7/10

I've been inspired to attend medical school several times in my life. Once, on a sunny spring day in grade school biology, I eagerly tore at a nugget of owl droppings. Then I moved on to the frog dissection. There the frog was, splayed out on the table, its limbs pinned down and ready for some scalpel action. A chance I had been waiting for, to cut some intestines open, a snip there, a stitch here, and 'voila!' the frog would be healed from its current state of death, and it would go hopping off into the stream by the soccer field. A skillful procedure done with nerves of steel and a steady hand.   The abdominal cavity of said frog was some parts liquified, jelly-fied, and stank of formaldehyde. I didn't know what was what, or how the damn frog died in the first place. Thoughthe spaghetti-like mess of bowels covered my hands, I kept on cutting. Years later, I wondered if this is what Dr. Troy from Nip/Tuck felt on the day of his first scrub-in during his 3rd year surgery rotation. My own private practice plastic surgery center was in sight, with the lambo sitting outside. Finally, the last organ plopped out of the gaping incision... the frog remained dead with guts everywhere. I ended up with a D+ in biology that year.  That's what playing Surgeon Simulator 2013 felt like.

This game is escapism turned up to 11. Use two hands IRL and half your keyboard space, plus your mouse, just to control one hand that doesn't even have a full motion range. Sound ridiculous? It is. Oh so hilariously ridiculous...  This is a game for those with a very broad sense of humour, or a well-hidden sadistic streak. When you tear out Bob's lung with a hammer, you have to either laugh, vomit or smile inwardly with sadistic glee. If you chose option one or three, then Surgeon Simulator is well worth the pricetag. If you chose option 2.... then don't watch the trailers.  The gameplay is really really hard to describe adequately; but it's like the drinking game version of the boardgame 'Operation'. Basically, you're taking bits out of Bob (all three patients are apparently named Bob), and then you put a couple of bits back in. All on two time limits - an actual clock, and the 'hard limit' of how much blood Bob can phyiscally lose before he/it dies.   And Bob will die a lot. Sometimes you'll even get an achievement for killing him. But there are a lot of 'oh great the drill is stuck in him, I'd better get the hammer to pull it out... great, now the hammer is stuck too, hand me the circular saw'. Eventually you get an understanding of how each tool works and how each body part works; and after a messy time learning all these things you can start performing surgical feats.   This game requires a mix of thought, motor skills, practice and patience. The patients, fortunately, are provided - make no mistake, if you tried performing surgeries in this manner IRL you *would* be going away for a long time. In fact, the thing you can leave at the door is realism - a working knowledge of anatomy may be helpful; but I'm thinking more of the kind of knowledge a butcher has than that of a medical professional. If you are a medical professional, leave all that Hippocratic Oath and 'duty of care' stuff behind in Surgeon Simulator; at least to begin with. One day it will come in useful as you make precision moves to complete the surgery, but in the early days it's just a case of beating and stabbing the internal organs around until they fall out.  I do reccomend this game as a casual, light-hearted bit of entertainment. Some people may like to take it further and develop the skills to be a 'pro surgeon', but a lot more players will just enjoy stabbing poor Bob with a drill. And that's an entirely valid way to play Surgeon Simulator; you can get all your money's worth and more out of that kind of slapstick 'hmm I wonder what happens when I...' messing around.

I could not want to play this game less.  After getting use to the loose (read: gimmicky) controls, you enter into you first surgery, a heart transplant. Step 1: crack open the rib cage as destructively as possible while also not causing massive internal hemoraging. While not causing your patient to bleed out is simple enough, cracking a rib cage with a hammer (or the less preferred bonesaw or dremmel) by controlling a flimsy wrist with the x and y axis on the mouse is frusturating and, worse, boring,   By my fifth try, I made it to the heart with my patient losing blood only at 3ml/s, but I felt nothing. No risk, no fun, and no pride in managing to become familiar with bad controls that were intentionally created to be bad.  It's like Demon Souls...if it were programmed by the old Titus team that made Superman 64.  Wait until it's on sale for $1 USD and then make sure you don't need that dollar for a pack of chips from a vending machine.

Surgeon Simulator is definitely an 'experience'. Most will likely find this game rather shallow and pointless, but as-it-is can be quite fun. I personally came into very skeptical but once booted I realized time had flown by and I was hooked messing around in someones body as chunks, bones, and tools went flying aroudn the room  My biggest frustration didn't reside with the completely intentionally absurd controls, but with the total lack of instruction of what to do next to perform a 'surgery'. Even passing the first surgery was a struggle only because it wasn't clear what was needed to be done. Maybe this was intentional, but on top of the wacky control system, this added an unneccesarry challenge I believe.  This will definetly not be a game for everyone, but if you have spare time and want to try something way out of left field, it can be worth a go for a bit. Don't expect it to be a long term satisfying game though.

Were this a 'calm player-objective driven sandbox' game where you could be fooling around for the most part, I could recommend this 'game' to be purchased. However, what we have in hands is actually something that tries to be as 'arcade' (read: pick-it-up-and-play-for-the-high score) as possible; and for the most part there is also only single solution, because of reason called 'developers dictated so'...  Controls aside, which have been already bashed enough already by others, there are some far more 'bugger' issues with this title. It all mainly comes down to both the limitation where hand/player can go around and the level layouts: Were one to drop the needed 'ingredient' or tool into floor, there is no way to retrieve these aside restarting the stage / 'murdering' the patient. Same thing happens when you accidentally push items far too away from your reach when 'magnet'-fingers of the player-hand fails to 'activate'. Then there are simply the item-layout causing huge problems when trying to achieve the main goal; either player-hand cannot be lowered enough due wrist boking into something and halting the decent. Or otherwise there are solid non-movable object preventing the operations itself.  The much advertised 'Meet the Medic'-stage is guilty of all the unplayability faults mentioned (and many other faults): Good luck    All in all, I certainly don't recommending to buy this game (at least alone). But otherwise if for some reason one gets this game to their collection, I for one certainly hope the player is going to face less of the bugs and such (Use bonesaw on ribcage -> lungs phase through <- ribcage still being intact, to name latest bugs I encountered alongside scalpel-immune innards).   On a random side-note, I've yet to still see or hear any other surgeon-sections or whole games that actually are not only more or less realistic, but fun to do than 'Life & Death'-series (flawed, and certainly far too ahead its time) and that one 'mini-game' in 'Chaos Break' (which for goodness sake was sort of like more-actiony 'Resident Evil', but with non-Earth-invading-cretures (and first introduction to sudokus to me (*I was doing sudokus way before they were cool*)). I can always keep wishing and forget that 'Trauma Center'-series was a thing (aside music of course, but that's the 'unfortunate' thing with various not-so-good-things; music alone for the most part is far better than the product it was shipped with)...

Unfortunately I went into this with something totally different in mind. I can definitely see the appeal for anyone who likes to kill time (no pun intended) doing infuriatingly difficult -- though somewhat entertaining -- tasks. Was I expecting an *actual* surgical simulation? No, not really; and to be honest the sound and blood effects are pretty entertaining on their own. I guess ultimately my disappointment arises from the fact that the sole purpose of the game really seems to be simply the fact that the surgeon's hand is incredibly imprecise and difficult to control. Yes, I can see to some degree the comedic value of accidentally knocking a jar into the patient's chest cavity or stabbing them in the heart when you meant to cut their esophagus, but at some point I had to ask myself, 'Am I playing this because I like fighting the game's insistence on not doing what I'm trying to control the hand to do, or because I like figuring out how best to perform the surgery and manage blood loss?' I will tell you that the game overwhelmingly shifts toward the former, and I realized that the vast majority of the time wasn't spent figuring out how to do the surgery and keep the patient alive, but simply and almost solely trying to control the surgeon himself. I got about halfway through before I decided I was tired of fighting the game itself rather than actually playing it. I guess I don't understand why the devs decided to put all the effort into developing decent graphics, sound effects, music, interface, etc., then phone it in on the controls.  If the point is the lack and difficulty of control, then I guess that wasn't something I understood going into it. So if a game based on fighting with the controls to manipulate an extremely difficult to maniuplate broken robotic quasi surgeon hand, then this game is for you. If that sounds like it would be a bit frustrating and unfulfilling, you'll want to pass on this game. I can assure you, the comedic value quickly gets replaced with frustration, annoyance, and regret at having spent the money.  6/10

Watched youtubers play this, and felt like I just had to get it!  Pros: The challenging aspect of the game is why you'd go for it. Expect to rage a little, but feel the relief once everything works out. Honestly, you get the hang of it after a while, so stick with it!  The idea of the game is pretty novel, to be honest! Usually simulators can be rather clunky and meaningless, but this one.. works just the way it is The music is pretty cool The achievements are quite fun to collect, and to aim for (A++ grades are no joke)  Cons: The tooth surgery for the ambulance can glitch out to a point where you are unable to complete the mission The corridor mode is pretty challenging, I cracked a few knuckles over that one. But it is the point (I guess)  All in all, this game is worth it, if you enjoy a rather unconventional game that kind of brings you to levels of frustration that is released by thrusting a middle finger in Bob's face, or by jamming a drill into his skull. I've done that so many times I should be arrested for manslaughter (haha). But still, this game is worth it, because gameplay is novel and with friends, the fun magnifies. :D Trust me, I'm a doctor.

Gobbleshaft?  Well, in Surgeon Simulator 2013 you can do all of this and more. This is a hilarious game and I definatly recommend it, although probably not to those who are sqemish. The physics and controls are hilarious and fun to use. There are lots of fun easter eggs to discover and great variety to the surgerys. Even though there are only three surgerys there are 3 different modes for each, Surgery, Ambulance & Space. These are all fun with their own challanges and hilarious mistakes to be made.  You probably might don't want to use any of these techniques in real life, somehow hacking someone's ribcage open with a hammer isn't really the correct way to get access to any organs underneath.  Great for a real surgeon who needs a bit of comic relief. 10/10!

You play as psychopathic Dr. Nigel, who, by a miracoulous event, turned from a lowly secretary with arthritis to one of the world's leading surgeon professionals. In Surgeon Simulator 2013, you'll cut, slice, hammer, and laser your way through seven levels of brutal torture to your patient. The connectivity between the doctor and player gives off new insight into the future of storytelling in video gaming. You are Nigel Burke. The choices he has made reflects into your deepest darkest self. As you place your patient's intestines on his face, you cannot help but to giggle or laugh. It's one of these similar events that shows your dark side. Overall, this game might be the darkest and comedic game I have ever played and to this day, I still dream about doing some Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom ♥♥♥♥ where I rip out a person's heart while shouting 'KALI MAH!' I wouldn't be surprised if this game was nominated for indie game of the year, but then I remembered that the controls are ♥♥♥♥ing difficult, so probably not.

A deep story about the value of human life and society as a whole. What lengths will you go to to save the life of this man. You are willing to give your all to save a virtual man who doesn't exist outside the level you are playing. What about when your all isn't good enough? What will you tell his virtual children? Child: 'Is my daddy coming home from the hospital soon?' You: 'I'm sorry little boy, but I dropped qtips in his brain and it killed him.' Child: '...'  The nature of your fellow humans reflects back on our feelings as members of society. You may be doing fine at your job, but then the ambulance driver takes a turn to quickly and a knife flys into his colon. You may desperately need someone to hold onto the lung so that you can save his life, but now matter how many timese you ask him the patient will refuse to help save his own life. You are the only one you can trust, and if you can't do it all on your own than you can't do it and you'll let everyone down.  10/10

It all feels as though you are moving around an arm on a stick and, if you are super lucky, pressing all the buttons will allow you to clumsily grab something - whether it was the item you wanted or not - in some orientation - which I guarantee will not be the way you wanted it.   You don't actually have to worry about anything, you can rip things out to your hearts content. You just need to replace what the objective is. And how you do that is not really clear. It all fells terribly amature-ish. It excels in making you want to throw your mouse against a wall thanks to it's terrible controls, but fails in everything else. I suggest you avoid this game at all costs.

Well i guess i should write a review for Surgeon Simulator. Normally when people play simulator games they are either bored or on the road to being board after a short while. this game is not like that. to put it quite simply, it's different from most simulators. it is a great game despite the flaws, one being the controls. The controls seem fairly odd and make the game difficult to play. It really takes time to get used to it but thankfully the menu you can practice your odd controls, even set your own if you cannot stand the default, which i did. I could stand it but moved a few keys so my hand was closer together (asdf and space + mouse)  other then that the game is quite difficult in working the hand and completing a few different surguries. it also plays with time, and working the needle to keep the patient from bleeding out.  I Recommend this game to anyone looking for a different take on the simulation games.

Surgeon Simulator 2013 brings the humorous web game to a more feature rich version that brings as much fun as the original prototype. The goal of each operation is to remove a failed organ and replace it with another, often with realism taking a step back for the gameplay. The controls can be likened to QWOP with its confusing and awkward controls, although getting a feel of them doesn't take too long to do each of the operations. Each operation can be summed up as break this bone or cut exactly here on the organ and remove it, and is loads of fun trying to flail around your hand. Graphically and musically it plays as parody of TV medical dramas like the first game with good music and funny yet semirealistic medical objects and organs. There's a small amount of operations with some variations, but the appeal is in the controls, physics, and humor. As an update to the popular web game, the full version of Surgeon Simulator 2013 brings humor and silliness to surgery to a very enhanced and appealing experience.
A must have for everyone seriously interested in medicine.

Since some people who love games like Farmer Simulator 2014 and Football Manager 2014: Electric Boogaloo will most likely impulse buy this game, let me warn you. This is not an 'actual' simulator. It is QWOP mixed with Trauma Center.  That being said, it's not that bad. Obviously, there will be some parts where you go 'COME ON MAN I BROKE HIS RIBS AND I'M PULLING LIKE CRAZY WHY THE HELL ISN'T THE LIVER COMING OUT?' And there will be other times when a tool or organ you need juuuuuuuuust slips out of reach and you have to restart the level. Again.   On the other hand, it IS intended to be balls-to-the-wall difficult, and those little moments after minutes of hardship where you haphazardly throw a new heart into the guy's chest gravity and it accepts it or when you do a 180-degree spoon flip or when you throw a brain into a man's head like a basketball are the best moments you'll ever feel.

this may not be true of everyone's experience, but for me, it was fun for the first 3 operations, then it got a bit samey, and the odd 'physics' weren't helping, but it wasn't terrible, so if you really are curious, try it.

Surgery (from the Greek: χειρουργική cheirourgikē (composed of χείρ, 'hand', and ἔργον, 'work'), via Latin: chirurgiae, meaning 'hand work') is an ancient medical specialty that uses operative manual and instrumental techniques on a patient to investigate and/or treat a pathological condition such as disease or injury, to help improve bodily function or appearance or to repair unwanted ruptured areas (for example, a perforated ear drum).  An act of performing surgery may be called a surgical procedure, operation, or simply surgery. In this context, the verb operate means to perform surgery. The adjective surgical means pertaining to surgery; e.g. surgical instruments or surgical nurse. The patient or subject on which the surgery is performed can be a person or an animal. A surgeon is a person who practices surgery and a surgeon's assistant is a person who practices surgical assistance. A surgical team is made up of surgeon, surgeon's assistant, anesthesia provider, circulating nurse and surgical technologist. Surgery usually spans minutes to hours, but it is typically not an ongoing or periodic type of treatment. The term surgery can also refer to the place where surgery is performed, or simply the office of a physician, dentist, or veterinarian.  In general, I like this game.

I did a transplant with a pen, tomahawk and a hand drill... never got congratulated once.  How about instead of going to school for a number of years, learning about the medical field and actually being trained and authorized to operate... you instead do it by yourself in the most unorthodox way possible! This game makes being a doctor look real easy!  So if you've seen Goat Simulator... then you get the idea of the realism of this game. Reality does not exist in this game's dictionary, so don't expect to be a real life surgeon in this game... you'll get disappointed. Expect laughs, giggles, and bad chills down your spine as you realize you just chopped a guy's head open with a damn tomahawk... talk about dark humor.  All in all, if you're sick and twisted, here's your entertainment then.    Thanks for reading! Check out these other links!   My Curator Group   Other Game Reviews

I only recommend Surgeon Sim on sale. Pay the full price and you will chuck your peripherals out the window.  Gameplay video of an attempt to help Bob...   Dr Giles Wilksmint   A quick run down in case you are thinking of getting this one:  + It's... different? + Sound effects are... meaty? + You can use a hammer.  - The controls... oh the controls... You will be bashing your keyboard and clicking your mouse harder than ever, often to very little avail. - It is... not relaxing. - Trial and error... trial and error... and then some. - You never really feel that you are in control of... anything. Part of the charm perhaps?  As stated above, only get it on sale for a lark and a laugh.
